Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 8: The sage Asita's predictions
Manual - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): Vol. Ka (1) and vol. Kha (2) pp. 12-13.

Sun of Faith - English: In the company of his disciple Naradatta, Asita the sage set out to behold the face of the Bodhisattva.
Manual - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): དེ་ནས་གྲོང་ཁྱེར་སེར་སྐྱའི་བཀོད་པ་གཞན་ཞིག་གི་ཁང་བཟང་དུ། ཡབ་ཀྱི་སྐུ་པང་དུ་བཞུགས་པ་ལ། མདུན་དུ་དྲང་སྲོང་ཁ་དོག་མི་ཤ་ཁ་ནག་པོ། རལ་པ་སེར་སྐྱ་འཛིངས་ཤིང་ཁ་སྤུ་ནག་པོ་ཅན།  ཚངས་སྐུད་དང་དབྱུག་གུ་སྤྱི་བླུགས་ཡོད་པ། རྒན་པའི་ཆ་བྱད་ཅན་ཞིག་གི་བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ལ་ལྟ་ཞིང་། ལག་པ་གཡས་ཅུང་ཟད་སྒྲེང་བ་དང་། ཕྱོགས་གཞན་ཞིག་ཏུ་དྲང་སྲོང་དེ་རྒྱལ་པོའི་དྲུང་དུ་མཆིལ་མ་འདོན་པའི་ཚུལ་བྱ་བ་དང་། ཕོ་བྲང་དེའི་ཕྱི་རོལ་ན་དྲང་སྲོང་དེ་ཚུར་ཡོང་དུས་ཀྱུས་མ་ཡོང་བ་དང་། ཕར་འགྲོ་དུས་ནི་སྒོའི་ཕྱི་ནས་དར་རས་སོགས་སྐྱང་བའི་སྟེང་། དེ་དང་ཉེ་བའི་བྲག་ཕུག་གཅིག་ཏུ་དེ་ཉིད་བསམ་གཏན་ལ་གནས་པའི་ཚུལ་དང་། དེའི་མདུན་དུ་དྲང་སྲོང་གཞོན་ནུ་གཅིག་འབྲི། དེ་དག་ནི་ལྷུམས་སུ་ཞུགས་པ་དང་བལྟམས་པའི་སྐོར་རོ།།   ༼ཁ༽དེ་ནས་མ་མ་བརྒྱས་སྐོར་བའི་བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་བྱིས་པའི་ཚུལ་གྱི་གསེར་གྱི་གཞོང་པ་ཤིན་ཏུ་ཆེ་བ་འབྲས་ཀྱིས་བཀང་བ། ཕྱོགས་གཅིག་ནས་གླང་པོ་ཆེ་མང་པོ་ལ་བཏགས་ལ། བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ཁྱེའུའི་ཕྱག་མཛུབ་གཅིག་གིས། གཞོང་པ་ནས་འཐེན་པས། གླང་པོ་ཆེ་རྣམས་ཀྱང་འདྲེད་སྟབས་སུ་ཚུར་དྲུད་པ། འབྲས་ཆེན་ནས་གསོལ་བའི་རྣམ་པ་ཡང་འབྲི་སྟེ། ཕྱག་གཡོན་པས་སྣོད་ནས་འཐེན་ཚུལ་དང། གཡས་པས་གསོལ་བའི་རྣམ་པ་བྱས་ན་ལེགས།
Manual - English: In Kapilavastu, in a mansion, the Buddha sits the king's lap. A sage looks at the Buddha and slightly held up his right hand. He is an old man with dark skin, unkempt grayish yellow hair, and black moustache. He carries a brahma thread, cane, and sacred water vase and pills (spyi blugs). When the sage is on his way to the palace, he is treated as an ordinary visitor. But when he leaves, he walks on the silk spread on the path spread outside the palace gate. In a cave, the sage abides in samadhi with a young man before him. [Vol. Kha (2)]: The Buddha is surrounded by a hundred nannies. There is a large golden tray filled with rice.  One side of the tray is tied to a flock of elephants with ropes. When the Buddha pulls the tray with one finger, he also pulls away all the elephants. The Buddha drinks rice gruel. It is better if the Buddha pulls the bowl with left hand and eats right-handed.

Sun of Faith - English: The two hermits completed the greater part of their journey by flying through the air;
but when they reached the outskirts of Kapilavastu, the Bodhisattva's involuntary magnificence radiated from him with such intensity that their magical powers faded away.
Thus when they arrived at the city gates, they did so on foot.
They made themselves known to the guard,
who informed the king.
Shuddhodana came to welcome the distinguished sage with all due ceremony.
He begged him to be seated upon a raised throne,
and after greeting him cordially, courteously asked the reason for his visit.
“It would give me great joy to see your son,” explained the sage.
“He is asleep. Perhaps it would be best to wait till he wakes,” the king responded.
“I will observe him in his sleep.”
Asita bent over the cradle and found that the child had his eyes wide open and was examining all the shadowy shapes around him.
The saint intoned: "The very finest horses sleep in the night/
Only a quarter of the time;
Repose lays its finger fitfully on the eyes
of the one who is only thinking about others."
The Sage felt very moved to find himself in the presence of so exceptional a child.
Scene working notes: This seems to simply be Taranātha's summary of Asita's previous praise.

Sun of Faith - English: The first wet-nurse then picked up the baby and showed him to the sage who, after a careful scrutiny,
turned to the king. “Sire, what sort of hints did the oracle-priests give regarding the young prince's future?”
The king accurately repeated the predictions concerning the two possible destines that the other sages had mentioned.
“Lord of the earth, those savants are wrong,” Asita asserted.
“A universal monarch is never born in an era torn by strife.
This child has within him the treasure of Dharma; he possesses extraordinary merit;
he will successfully combat all forms of evil and become a buddha.
Universal monarchs do display the thirty-two marks, but they always appear blurred or dim.
The signs upon this child are perfectly distinct: he will be a buddha.”
With the clairvoyance of a great sage, Asita looked into the time to come:
Scene working notes: In the Vinayavastu passage, Asita also predicts that the child will leave his home at age 29 and perform austerities for six years.

as he realized that he would be unable to participate in the Dharma's efflorescence, his eyes filled with tears.
Fearful that the saint had detected some harmful indication that might bear on his son's health, the king plied him with questions.
To which the sage respnded: "Should even rocks hail down upon this child, his life would suffer no harm.

Sun of Faith - English: And, therefore, I shall not attain [perfect] peace,
Alnd although I have met this treasury of the perfect teaching,
I myself, will not be able to enjoy its benefits before I die
The sage said this among other things.
When it was time for the great saint to go, The king and the ministers who had had the roads bedecked in his honor, escorted him to the city gates.
Once back, Asita's miraculous powers returned.
One day shortly after these events, the Bodhisattva was sitting in his nurse's lap eating with great relish some rice mixed with bits of meat in a golden bowl.
Lest the child overeat and make himself sick, the nurse decided to cover the bowl with a lid.
The little prince would not let her. She attempted to take the vessel away from the infant but he clutched it tight.
The king, the queen, the ministers and all the court tried turn by turn to make the baby let go of the bowl—all in vain.

Finally, to put an end to the matter, one end of a piece of strong cord was tied round the golden bowl, and the other end pulled—first, by one elephant, then two elephants—all the way up to five hundred elephants
but the Bodhisattva kept his hold with just one finger of his left hand which gently tugged the receptacle towards him.
“A child who can tow five hundred elephants with his left hand can tow a thousand with both!” the people cried in total astonishment.
In honor of this incident, they named him Sahasra-manyu, ‘strong as a thousand elephants.’
